author: r.alxz
content: i'm reading the latest version of the Engine API specification.md and I'm not sure if i'm missing it but i'm not seeing a description of what `buildProcessId` is or should be, other than it's 8 bytes

author: m.kalinin
content: It should be a value that uniquely identifies the build process. It's up to EL client implementation to decide how exactly this value is sampled. CL stores this 8 bytes on its side no matter what do they mean and some time later passes them to `getPayload` to request the payload that has been built

author: r.alxz
content: ok, sounds good, thanks!

author: m.kalinin
content: What is the fork choice state that is passed onto `forkchoiceUpdated` call to initiate the build process for the *first* payload in the network?

author: shanaq
content:
In the latest spec there is a requirement for the EL client to execute in the order of request IDs. Is it correct that only in the context of concurrent rpc calls to the EL client that calls be executed in order?
For instance, if request IDs 1, 9, 10 are sent but only 1 and 10 are received, the client could be waiting for request ID 9 forever. Therefore the ordering of calls would only occur if both 9 and 10 are received at the same time.
If that is the case, since 1 EL client can respond to many CL clients, what happens in the case that 2 CL clients send two requests with a race condition with different but increasing request IDs?

author: m.kalinin
content:
There is a statement in the spec:
> On the other hand, generic many-to-one Consensus Layer to Execution Layer configurations are not supported out-of-the-box. 

This kind of conflicts should be solved on the implementation level

author: m.kalinin
content: Actually, it's a good question what to do if 10th request has already been processed and 9th has just arrived. For the `forkchoiceUpdated` calls 9th must not be applied in this case. For `executePayload` -- it could be executed if there are no missing data required for the execution of this payload

author: m.kalinin
content: If CL respects the order of egress messages and does not send the next message until hears from EL that it's been received successfully then messages shouldn't be lost and messed up

author: marioevz
content:
Hi all, I've created several test vectors for EIP-4399 here: https://github.com/marioevz/kintsugi_testing/tree/main/tests/EIP4399
Each test vector is basically a json file with a genesis block and then a series of "steps", where each one is an RPC method call, its parameters, and the expected response.
We've run all of them against geth and so far the tests found one (already fixed) issue with the opcode, but are now all passing, so if you want to run them against another client please let me know üëç
